title: Assistant Feels Over-Corrected
summary: Assistant says they feel micromanaged. Build trust around feedback: ask what support they need and how you can give feedback better; agree on when you'll step in.

scene.setting: Assistant says they feel micromanaged. You may feel defensive or dismissive; the hidden risk is ignoring their perception and engagement dropping. The decision point is protect authority vs build trust.

beats.narration: They've shared that they feel over-corrected. The decision point is explain standards or ask how to give feedback better.

dialogue.speaker: lead
dialogue.line: I hear you. What support do you need, and how can I give feedback in a way that feels helpful instead of micromanaging?

choices.label: Explain that you expect excellence and high standards.

steps.step: Add: focus on outcomes not every step; ask how they prefer feedback; check-in rhythm that feels supportive.

leader_lines: Standards stay—and I want to give feedback in a way that works for you.
How do you set standards without over-correcting?
questions: How do you prefer to get feedback?
scripts.closing_line: Focus on outcomes; ask preference; supportive check-in rhythm.

choices.label: Ask what support they need and how you can give feedback better.

steps.step: Ask what support and how to give feedback better.
Align on when and how: private, specific, forward-looking; ask before giving; separate praise from correction.

leader_lines: What would make feedback feel safe and useful?
When do you want me to step in—safety only, key outcomes?
questions: How do you make feedback feel safe?
scripts.closing_line: Private, specific, forward-looking; ask before giving; separate praise from correction.

steps.step: Agree on key checkpoints only; feedback in writing when possible; regular 1:1 for alignment.

leader_lines: Less feedback isn't the same as safer feedback. Let's agree on when I step in.
How do we balance support and standards?
scripts.closing_line: Key checkpoints only; feedback in writing when possible; regular 1:1.

choices.label: Acknowledge their feeling and suggest we agree on when you'll step in.

steps.step: Acknowledge; agree on when you'll step in: safety/compliance only, key outcomes only, or after they've had a chance to try.

leader_lines: I hear you. When should I step in—safety only, key outcomes, or after you've tried?
scripts.closing_line: Safety or compliance only; key outcomes; or after they try.

system_prompts.mirror_call: Did you protect authority or build trust?

outcomes.message: They may feel unheard. Trust may not improve.
reflection_questions: What would have changed with ask-what-support?
How do you set standards without over-correcting?

outcomes.message: They feel heard. When and how to give feedback are aligned; trust and clarity improved.
reflection_questions: What agreement on when to step in helped most?
How do you make feedback feel safe?

tsp.weekly_pulse_prompt: This week I built trust around feedback. (1-5)
